Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Time Dependent Behavior of Flexible Active Composites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Flexible active composite materials combine the light weight and durability of polymers and the actuation and sensing capabilities of piezoelectric ceramics. One example of achieving active flexible composites is by embedding ferroelectric ceramic fibers in a homogeneous polymeric matrix. Active composite materials find use in many engineering applications that require controllable reconfiguration of complex 3D shapes, such as artificial skins, implantable and energy harvesting devices, or flexible robots for use in hazardous environments to name a few. Similarly, the coupled behavior makes them attractive candidates for sensors for structural health monitoring applications, i.e. damage detection in civil infrastructures such as bridges. However, despite their great potential, many of the active composite materials in use today experience suboptimal performance as well as property degradation over time. This grant addresses existing knowledge gaps by focusing on the fundamental research needed to accelerate the development of flexible active composite materials with improved long-term performance. In addition, the PIs will focus on outreach and education goals that will improve the depth, rate, and retention of learning in the training of future engineers, broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM-related fields and improve the scientific literacy of the public.

Despite the long history of the use of lead zirconate titanate (PZT) fiber-based composites, important engineering challenges still remain in understanding and predicting their behavior. These challenges are primarily related to the different frequency (rate) dependent hysteretic responses of the polymers and PZT constituents and the gradual changes in their properties under continuous cyclic loadings. This research will address this important gap in knowledge using an integrated experimental and numerical approach that is expected to have positive consequences on the reliability and widespread use of flexible active composite materials in critical applications. Models will be built to integrate the time-dependent and electro-mechanical coupled responses of the different constituents to the overall deformations in flexible active composite materials. Additionally, these models will be enhanced to incorporate the gradual changes in the nonlinear properties of the active composites and their constituents under various electro-mechanical loading conditions. Based on the models, prototype composites with targeted improved performance behaviors will be processed and characterized. Understanding the relationships between processing and life performance of flexible active composite materials will inform manufacturing and enable wide-spread utilization of such systems for engineering applications.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Proposal: Time-dependent Hysteretic Responses and Cyclic Loading Behavior of Flexible Electro-Active Composites

 

Project Outcome

 

Flexible electro-active composites are enabling actuator technology for many engineering applications that require controllable reconfiguration of complex 3D shapes. Similarly, their coupled mechanism makes them ideal sensors for structural health monitoring applications. One example of achieving active flexible composites is by embedding ferroelectric ceramics fibers, typically lead zirconate titanate (PZT) in homogeneous polymeric matrix, so-called 1-3 composites. Despite the long history in PZT fiber-based composites, important intellectual challenges still remain unsolved in their behavior, primarily relating to the different frequency (rate) dependent hysteretic responses of the polymers and PZT constituents and the gradual changes in their properties under continuous cyclic loadings. Our NSF-funded research addressed these knowledge gaps by focusing on: 1) exploring the role of the load transfer mechanisms between the active (PZT fiber) and non-active constituents (polymer matrix and adhesive) and their time-dependent hysteretic responses under coupled multi-field inputs, 2) understanding the impact of the polymer matrix properties on coupled response of active composites, and 3) using integrated experimental and numerical approaches with positive consequences on their reliability and widespread use in critical applications. We developed unique experimental set-ups where we directly tested individual PZT fibers in an electromechanical environment that was consistent with the one they experienced in an active fiber composite, i.e., using interdigitated electrodes (IDEs) and considering both the direct and converse piezoelectric effects. We validated the obtained properties through finite element analysis approach, for a regular planar configuration and for the IDE configuration. The newly measured direct and converse piezoelectric coefficients of individual PZT fibers using IDEs were then compared to those obtained for the active fiber composite (where the fibers were immersed in a non-active polymer matrix) to ascertain the effect of the polymer matrix and its impact on time-dependent and temperature-dependent hysteretic responses. Uncovering the physical mechanisms responsible for the time-dependent response and the cyclic loading-induced property degradation in active composites is key to implementing materials-based and processing-based improvement in next-generation active composites. Resolving these challenges leads to materials ameliorations resulting in significantly improved next-generation active composites. Research results and corresponding unique and new characterization techniques were incorporated in a graduate course to enhance the interdisciplinary training of graduate students. A number of outreach activities targeting high school and first-year undergraduate students were organized over the three-year span of the project. Two graduate students and three undergraduate students were engaged in the research during the three-year of the project.

 


Last Modified: 03/28/2018
Modified by: Zoubeida Ounaies

Resolving these challenges leads to materials ameliorations resulting in significantly improved next-generation active composites.
